awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of New Security Technologies on Urban Life
awd_abstract_narration:
Security apparatuses are rapidly changing because of advances in technology. Scientists have established that like all new technologies, security systems can have important social and cultural impacts for the communities in which they are adopted.  New security paradigms, and the privatization of security services, offer an opportunity for anthropological science to evaluate the socio-cultural variation in methods of social regulation and the efficacy of these technologies in abating crime. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, scientifically grounded fieldwork, explores what impact these new security technologies are having on urban life, and how the implementation of these technologies and the form that they take is influenced cultural and social variability.

University of California, Irvine doctoral student Kimberley McKinson, under the guidance of Dr. William Maurer will explore how contemporary notions of home security are shaped both by new technologies as well as by the social, historical and material legacies of regulation and discipline. Understanding urban residential life requires more than taking into account macro-level economic, legal and state discourses and practices. As such, the researcher will examine the production of the securitized home in order to study the ways in which socio-historical memory is being figured and refigured as today's urban dwellers become increasingly more involved in the domain of security and shift between metal, electronic and social modes of security at the spatial scales of the home, neighborhood and city. Data for this project will be collected through ethnographic fieldwork with residents of varying socio-economic backgrounds in their homes and community, with metal artisans in their workshops and at building sites and with private electronic security technicians and staff as they install, repair and design electronic security packages for clients. The researcher will use a variety of qualitative methods that will include participant observation, interviews, movement analysis, photography and videography, sketch-work and document research and archival research. This research project is important because it will recognize the home as a critical site in the study of security and as a way to think about spatial governance in its most domestic and pedestrian manifestation. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, research findings from this project will be useful to academics, policy makers and security specialists who seek to understand a security paradigm as a critical analytic for studying contemporary urban life.

This project investigates Kingston’s urban security ecology – what the co-PI defines as, the assemblage of and relationships between actors, artifacts, apparatuses and technologies across space and time that help to constitute what security is, how it is lived and perceptions of it in Kingston – in order to analyze the ways in which contemporary ideas about security and safety are shaping and being shaped by socio-historical narratives about the nation, nation-building, race, citizenship, violence, discipline, the home and property. Based on over a year of ethnographic fieldwork in Kingston with local residents, state actors, metal artisans, local police and electronic security specialists, this project connects the practices of these actors and demonstrates how they discursively, socially, technologically, aesthetically and infrastructurally create and circulate an aesthetics of security that organizes social life in the city. This research project is guided by an ethnographic, empirical and archival architecture that grounds the research through deep attention to how Kingston’s contemporary security moment is manifested in an urban space living with the historical legacies of slavery, colonialism and post-colonialism. These historical landscapes were defined in large part by the violent disciplining of black bodies, the emergence of a rights-disregarding police force known for extrajudicial violence and the perception of the inability of the state to provide security as a public good. In focusing on how these historical moments constructed and delineated racialized Jamaican bodies and identities, this project thus investigates Kingston as a critical black geography, one whose urban domestic landscape speaks to continuities and discontinuities in discourses and practices of discipline, control, safety and security.

The major findings of this research show the importance of studying security in high crime cities like Kingston, and by extension, high crime cities in the US and in the global South. Critical scholarship on high crime cities has examined the phenomenon of crime through an emphasis on the spectacle of violence and the pathologized criminal. The results of this project suggest that artifacts, technologies, discourses and social practices of security, and the ways in which they are mobilized by residents represent an important way in which social life is organized in the city. Moreover, the research suggests that these technologies, discourses and practices are operating at multiple scalar levels that span the home, community, city and nation. A major result of this project has been an understanding of the profound impact of crime on urban residential life, an understanding which requires more than taking into account political and legal regimes of power and greater attention to the politics of the everyday. This project will have a significant theoretical and empirical impact inside and outside of the discipline of anthropology by contributing to scholarship on urban security, crime and violence and material culture. By investigating how Jamaicans in urban Kingston produce, consume and organize a security paradigm, this project highlights the need for anthropology and related disciplines to recognize security as a critical analytic for studying urban social life. This project’s attention to how urban residents are using new security technologies as well as social practices such as neighborhood watches, suggests the importance of addressing the topic of security in more nuanced ways. This project stands to make contributions to social science discussions on urban security and space by re-situating the domestic space as an important unit of analysis.
